qas.question: Who was allowed to wear gamrents dyed with Tyrian purple in ancient Rome?
Who was allowed to wear feather cloaks and palaoa in old school Hawaiian society?
What right were lower caste women required to pay a tax to acquire?

answers.text: the right to cover their upper body

qas.question: What country once only allowed their emperor to wear yellow?
Who is not allowed to wear garments dyed purple in ancient Rome
What is not used to indicate rancor status?
In one country could the Emperor not wear yellow?
what kind of laws do not regulate what people could wear

context: In some societies, <b6_0>clothing<b6_0/> may be used to indicate rank or status. In ancient Rome, for example, only <a0_0><b5_0>senators<b5_0/><a0_0/> could wear garments dyed with Tyrian purple. In traditional Hawaiian society, only <a1_0>high-ranking chiefs<a1_0/> could wear feather cloaks and palaoa, or carved whale teeth. Under the Travancore Kingdom of Kerala, (India), lower caste women had to pay a tax for <a2_0>the right to cover their upper body<a2_0/>. In <a3_0><b7_0>China<a3_0/>,<b7_0/> before establishment of the republic, only the emperor could wear yellow. History provides many examples of <b8_0>elaborate sumptuary laws<b8_0/> that regulated what people could wear. In societies without such laws, which includes most modern societies, social status is instead signaled by the purchase of rare or luxury items that are limited by cost to those with wealth or status. In addition, peer pressure influences <a4_0>clothing choice<a4_0/>.
